instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message:
This board is fully functional but the fans spin up after a few seconds. I've tried it in an entirely different case and it does the same thing. I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5871</TRANSISTOR> being that it was one of the few areas to be hit. No change. Online test shows no issues. I've attached pictures taken before cleaning. The only other area that seemed to get hit was the backlight circuit and that's all good. Not sure where to go next.


[ATTACH type="full"]59457[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]59458[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message:
Run HWMonitor and look for any strange temp value.
Also try disconnecting webcam.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message:
No change after disconnecting webcam.

I've tried this board in a known-good case and it does the same thing.

Heatpipe Outgoing Air is at 128C. I'm trying now to figure out where that sensor is.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message: Check <CHIP>U5850</CHIP>/60/70 areas and connections to their sensors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message: <CHIP>U5860</CHIP> was where there was some light sign of the spill. I replaced <CHIP>U5860</CHIP> and the 3 components above it. The fan still spins up but Heatpipe Outgoing Air is now down to a normal 30C. Everything seems very clean and solid around <CHIP>U5860</CHIP>, and in general. Nothing burnt. No blown pads or traces. The spill was very minimal. I'm stumped why the fan is still spinning up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message:
The sensors are placed far away.
Did you check all them and traces?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message: The sensors are all inside of big chips? Is that correct? So my goal is to just look for blown traces/connections?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message: Not sure what to do with this besides give up. I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5871</TRANSISTOR> because it got hit. I replaced <CHIP>U5870</CHIP> also just in case. <TRANSISTOR>Q5872</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5873</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5874</TRANSISTOR> are all good. Lines and measurements are all good compared to a good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message:
Try removing <CAPACITOR>C5871</CAPACITOR>.
Did you check traces from <TRANSISTOR>Q5871</TRANSISTOR> to <CHIP>U5870</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message: Yes, traces are all good. Continuity is there. I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5871</TRANSISTOR> again just in case. No change. Removed <CAPACITOR>C5871</CAPACITOR>. Fan still spins up the same way. Nothing changed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message:
Install Mac Speed Fan and set the fan speed to follow a specific sensor.
Or just set fixed speed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message: Isn't this issue going to slow the computer down? Isn't it being clocked down?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message: NO, if is not slow now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning up
threads.message: Ok, I haven't fully tested it for performance, but I'll try it. I'm going to put that capacitor back on and give it a try with fan control.
